title: Supported authentication types for Rest Executor 2.0 endpoints
content:
Rest Executor 2.0 endpoints support the following types of authentication.

 
The maximum length allowed for the top-level domain for base URLs is 20 characters.

Service Management

This type is dedicated to integration with another Service Management system.

Configuring an endpoint with the Service Management authentication type

Field Value
Agent

Select Agentless (if not using the OPB Agent) or the OPB agent created for the endpoint.
Authentication type Select Service Management.
Protocol Select https.
Base URL Enter the base URL of the target Service Management system: https://<FQDN>
Tenant ID Enter the tenant ID of the target Service Management system.

Username

(if not using the OPB Agent)

 Enter the username of the integration user for connecting to the target Service Management system.

Password

(if not using the OPB Agent)

 Enter the password of the integration user for connecting to the target Service Management system.

Credentials

(if using the OPB Agent)

 Select the credentials record that you've created for the endpoint in the Endpoint Credentials Manager. 

Generic

This type is for integration with systems that use some form of token-based HTTP authentication schemes.

Such authentication schemes work like this:

  • The client sends a request with user credential data (such as username and password) to the authentication server.
  • The authentication server verifies the identity of the client. After successful verification, the server sends a token back to the client.
  • The client includes the token in subsequent requests that it sends to the resource server.
  • The resource server verifies the token and returns the resources to the client.

This type requires you to construct the HTTP message (header and body) sent to the authentication server, and construct HTTP headers (by using data returned from the authentication server) that are appended to all requests that are sent to the resource server. Note that normally you need to configure only headers that are related with tokens or cookie data that must be retrieved from the authentication response. The requests for various connectors already contain other required headers.

For details about how to construct the HTTP messages and header, click the help icon in each section of the Endpoint configuration form for this type.

Configuring an endpoint with the Generic authentication type

Field Value
General Configuration section

Select Agentless (if not using the OPB Agent) or the OPB agent created for the endpoint.
Authentication type Select Generic.

Base URL Enter the base URL of the target system: https://<FQDN>

Enter the authentication URL of the target system.

(if not using the OPB Agent)

Certificate format

(if not using the OPB Agent)

(if not using the OPB Agent)

Configure authentication request section

Construct headers and body for requests sent to the authentication server. If the requests (or subsequent requests) include sensitive data, enter the data in the Encrypted data section. After entering the request headers and body, click Test connection to validate the configuration.
Encrypted data

If you must send sensitive data in various parts (header, body, cookie) of the requests (authentication requests or subsequent requests), enter the data in this section.  Data entered in this section will be masked with asterisks when the user enters it on the UI, and encrypted when it is saved.

Click +Add, enter the parameter name in the Parameter field, and then do either of the following, depending on whether you use the OPB Agent:

  • If not using the OPB Agent, enter the sensitive data in the Value field.

  • If using the OPB Agent, create a credentials record (with the Generic Auth type) for the sensitive data in the Endpoint Credentials Manager (enter the sensitive data in the Password/Confirm password fields), and then select the name for the credentials record in the drop-down list of the Value field.

     
    The sensitive data you enter in the Password fields in the Credentials Manager can't contain these special characters: $, \. Otherwise, the endpoint will fail to work.

You can reference the sensitive data by using this syntax when constructing the requests later: ${<parameter name>}. Example: ${password}.
Header Add key-value pairs to define header fields for the authentication request.
Method

GET - used to request data from a specified resource

POST - used to send data to a server to update a resource
Body

Enter the text that represents the message body (in JSON format) for the authentication request.

If you set Content-Type as application/json in Header, input the data in JSON format. For example: {"user":"peter","password":"${password}"}, where ${password} is reference of Encrypted data parameter.

If you set Content-Type as application/ x-www-form-urlencoded in Header, input the data with key, value separated by & when there are multiple data values. For example: company_id=mycompany&client_id=${client_id}&grant_type=urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:saml2-bearer&assertion=${SAML_assertion}, where ${client_id} and ${SAML_assertion} are reference of encrypted data parameters.

Extract data from authentication response section

Extract properties from various parts of the authentication response so that the properties can be used in subsequent requests. To extract a property, click +Add, and then specify values for the following fields.
Parameter

Specify a parameter name that stores the extracted data. Example: user_id.

You can reference the parameter value by using this syntax when constructing the requests later: ${<parameter name>}. Example: ${user_id}
HTTP element Select the HTTP element of the authentication response from which to extract the data: Header, Cookie, or Body.
Expression

Enter an expression that retrieves the value from the specified HTTP element. The expression to use depends on the HTTP element:

  • Header or Cookie: Directly enter the header or cookie field name.
  • Body:

    If you set Content-Type as application/json in Header, input the data in JSON format. For example: {"user":"peter","password":"${password}"}, where ${password} is reference of Encrypted data parameter.

    If you set Content-Type as application/ x-www-form-urlencoded in Header, input the data with key, value separated by & when there are multiple data values. For example: company_id=mycompany&client_id=${client_id}&grant_type=urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:saml2-bearer&assertion=${SAML_assertion}, where ${client_id} and ${SAML_assertion} are reference of encrypted data parameters.

Configure headers and cookies for subsequent requests section

Construct headers and cookies for requests that are sent after the authentication process is completed by clicking +Add. For each entry added, specify values for the following fields.
Key Specify the field name to add.
HTTP element Specify the HTTP element to which this field belongs: Header or Cookie.
Expression Enter a value for the field. You can enter a literal value or reference an encrypted value or a value extracted from the authentication response (by using the ${<parameter name>} syntax). You can also combine a literal value with a referenced value. Example: Bearer $<token>.

No Auth

This type is for integration with systems that don't use typical authentication schemes. For such systems, requests are sent without including user credentials in the request header.

This type supports appending headers to the requests that are sent to the resource server.

Configure headers and cookies for subsequent requests section

Construct headers and cookies for requests that are sent to the target system by clicking +Add. For each entry added, specify values for the following fields.

HTTP element Specify the HTTP element to which this field belongs: Header or Cookie.
Value Enter a value for the field. You can enter only a literal value. Example: application/json.

OAuth 2.0

This type is for integration with external systems that support the OAuth 2.0 authorization framework.

 

Currently, the Integration Studio supports only the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code and Client Credentials grant types; it doesn't support Implicit and Resource Owner Password Credentials grant types, as well as any extension grant types.

Additionally, our OAuth 2.0 implementation supports only the standard behavior and properties as outlined in the OAuth 2.0 specification. If the external system includes some custom properties or behavior that deviates from the OAuth 2.0 standard, then you can't use the OAuth 2.0 endpoint to integrate with the system.

What external systems can use the OAuth 2.0 endpoint

To be able to integrate with Service Management by using the OAuth 2.0 endpoint, the external system must satisfy the following conditions:

  • It supports integrations based on the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code or Client Credentials grant type. Read the vendor documentation to find this out. 
  • (Authorization Code grant type only) The external system's authorization server must return a refresh token after successfully completing the "request access token" flow. Different vendors use different methods to instruct the authorization server to return the optional refresh token. For example, some vendors require the user to add a value offline_access to the scope query parameter of the authorization URL.

Prerequisites

Before you configure an OAuth 2.0 endpoint, you must complete the following prerequisites in the external system:

 
In this document, we reference various OAuth-related properties by using the terminology in the OAuth 2.0 specification. The external system vendor might use different terms for these properties.
  • Register an application in the external system for the endpoint.
  • (Authorization Code grant type only) Enter https://<External_access_host>/rest/<Service Management_tenant_Id>/opb/oauth/callback as the redirect URL for the application.
  • Obtain the client Id and the client secret associated with the application.
  • (Authorization Code grant type only) Obtain the authorization URL for the external system from the vendor's developer documentation.
  • Obtain the token URL for the external system from the vendor's developer documentation.
  • Obtain the scopes (or permissions) that you assigned to the application during application registration. Take note of the code (as opposed to the display name) for the scopes.

If Service Management must connect to the target system specified by the endpoint through a proxy server, configure the proxy server in the Suite Administration portal (Configurations > Proxy settings). Proxy server configuration isn't necessary if Service Management is deployed in a SaaS environment.

Setting up the endpoint (Authorization Code grant type)

To configure an OAuth 2.0 endpoint for the Authorization Code grant type, perform the following steps:

  1. Select the REST Executor 2.0 endpoint, and then click Configure.
  2. Select Agentless in the Agent field.
  3. Select OAuth 2.0 from the Authentication Type list.
  4. Select https in the Protocol field.
  5. Enter the base URL of the target system in the Base URL field.
  6. Select X.509 in the Certificate type field.
  7. Select PEM in the Certificate format field.
  8. Open the root CA certificate file of the target system in a text editor, and then copy and paste the content to the Server certificate field.
  9. If you want the Integration Studio to send notification emails to integration administrators when the Integration Studio's attempt to refresh the access token fails, select the Enable email notification for token expiration checkbox and specify the email recipients.
  10. In the Get token configuration section, select Authorization Code from the Grant Type field, and then enter the values you obtained in the prerequisite section in the Client ID, Client Secret, Authorization URL, Token URL, and Scope fields. Note that if the integration associated with the endpoint requires multiple scopes, you must separate the scopes with space.

  11. For what value to enter for the State field, follow the vendor documentation. If no guidance is provided in the vendor documentation, enter a random value in the State field. This parameter is used only to prevent the access token from being hijacked.

     
    This field accepts only alphanumeric characters.
  12. Select whether to include the client Id and client secret in the request header or request body when making access token requests. Choose a method supported or recommended by the vendor. Check the vendor's developer documentation for details.

  13. (Optional) If the external system's OAuth implementation supports additional custom parameters (included as query parameters) in the authorization request flow, click Add in the Advanced options section to see if the parameters are available in the Key list; if available, add the parameters.

    Alternatively, append custom query parameters directly after the authorization URL, like this: https://auth.example.com/authorize?prompt=consent, where prompt is a custom parameter, and https://auth.example.com/authorize is the authorization URL. This way, you can add any custom parameters to the authorization request.

  14. Click Get token to generate an access token and a refresh token that the endpoint's associated integration uses. First, you will be redirected to the login page of the external system. After successful login, another dialog will be displayed, where you are prompted to consent to your application's scopes (or permissions). After you grant consent, an access token is generated (with the Available token status).

    Behind the scenes, clicking Get token initiates the OAuth 2.0 authorization request flow, and completing the login and consent processes initiates the access token request flow.

     
    The endpoint configuration is saved when you click Get token.
     
    Disable your browser's popup blocker. Otherwise, the external system's login screen and scope consent screen might not be displayed.

  15. Click Save. For the OAuth endpoint to work, you must generate the token before clicking Save. Otherwise, you just saved the configuration and the endpoint can't be used yet.

Setting up the endpoint (Client Credentials grant type)

To configure an OAuth 2.0 endpoint for the Client Credentials grant type, perform the following steps:

  1. Select the REST Executor 2.0 endpoint, and then click Configure.
  2. Select Agentless in the Agent field.
  3. Select OAuth 2.0 from the Authentication Type list.
  4. Select https in the Protocol field.
  5. Enter the base URL of the target system in the Base URL field.
  6. Select X.509 in the Certificate type field.
  7. Select PEM in the Certificate format field.
  8. Open the root CA certificate file of the target system in a text editor, and then copy and paste the content to the Server certificate field.

  9. If you want the Integration Studio to send notification emails to integration administrators when the Integration Studio's attempt to generate the token fails, select the Enable email notification for token expiration checkbox and specify the email recipients.

     
     The Integration Studio sends notifications after three token generation attempts fail. To ensure that the system sends notifications each time the token becomes invalid, we recommend that you configure retry policy with a retry count greater than 3 on all target system actions for the integrations that use this endpoint.
  10. In the Get token configuration section, select Client Credentials from the Grant Type field, and then enter the values you obtained in the prerequisite section in the Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL, and Scope fields. Note that if the integration associated with the endpoint requires multiple scopes, you must separate the scopes with space.

  11. Select whether to include the client Id and client secret in the request header or request body when making access token requests. Choose a method supported or recommended by the vendor. Check the vendor's developer documentation for details.

  12. (Optional) If the external system's OAuth implementation supports additional custom parameters in access token requests, click Add in the Advanced options section to see if the parameters are available in the Key list; if available, add the parameters. These parameters will be included in the body of the requests.

  13. Click Test connection to verify that the system can successfully generate the token by using the configured value.

Token management (Authorization Code grant type only)

Token status

A token in the OAuth 2.0 endpoint can have one of these statuses:

  • Available. This indicates that the token has been generated, but you must save the endpoint for the token to be usable by integrations. The token goes into this status after you successfully complete the "get token" process.
  • Active. This indicates that the token is valid and can be used by integrations. The token goes into this status after you successfully complete the "get token" process and save the endpoint.
  • Inactive. This is the initial token status. An Active token goes into this status when the token becomes invalid (for example, when the refresh token expires or gets revoked from the external system).

Token refresh (automatic background process)

Every day, the Integration Studio makes a refresh request to the token endpoint by using the refresh token. The purpose of this background process is to extend the lifetime of the refresh token and prevent token expiration.

If errors occur during the refresh request process, the token will become Inactive, and if configured, a notification email will be sent to the specified integration administrators. An administrator must open the Endpoint page to regenerate the token.

Token regeneration

You need to regenerate the token in one of the following scenarios:

  • When any property that is configured in the OAuth endpoint needs to be changed in the application you registered in the external system. For example, when the client secret changes or when you want to modify the scopes granted to the application.
  • When the token becomes invalid, for example, when the refresh token expires or gets revoked from the external system. You will see that the token becomes Inactive on the Endpoint page.

To regenerate the token, go through the "get token" process again by clicking Get token. Note that if the current token is still Active, a Clear token button is displayed in place of the Get token button. You must click Clear token to make the Get token button appear. You can update the OAuth-related details of an endpoint with an Active token only after you clear the endpoint's current token.

SAP SuccessFactors OAuth 2.0

This type is dedicated to integration with SAP SuccessFactors.

 
To integrate with SAP SuccessFactors, you must use SAP SuccessFactors OAuth 2.0 instead of the generic OAuth 2.0 authentication type.

Configuring an endpoint with the SAP SuccessFactors OAuth 2.0 authentication type

As a prerequisite, register Service Management as an OAuth2 client application in the Admin Center of SAP SuccessFactors. For details, see the SAP SuccessFactors documentation.

Then, create and configure an endpoint with the SAP SuccessFactors OAuth 2.0 authentication type based on the configuration of the OAuth2 client application registered in the Admin Center of SAP SuccessFactors.

Field Value
Agent

Select Agentless for a direct connection to SAP SuccessFactors.
Authentication type Select SAP SuccessFactors OAuth 2.0.
Protocol Select https.
Base URL

Enter the URL of the SAP SuccessFactors API Server. Example: https://apiyy.successfactors.com/

Check here to find the API Server of your instance.
Token URL

Enter the token URL from which you request the OAuth token for SuccessFactors: https://<api-server>/oauth/token
Company ID Enter the company ID obtained from the SuccessFactors Admin Center.
Client ID Enter the API key generated in the SuccessFactors Admin Center.
User ID Enter the user ID that can access the application. The user ID is the same as the one configured in the SuccessFactors Admin Center.
Private key

Enter the private key of the X.509 certificate configured or generated in the SuccessFactors Admin Center.

Note that when copying the private key,  copy the key content only without the beginning (-----BEGIN ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY-----) and ending (-----END ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY-----) lines.
Certificate type Leave it empty.
Certificate format Leave it empty.
Server certificate

Leave it empty.

After completing the configuration, click Test connection to validate the configuration.

AWS Signature

This type is dedicated to integration with Amazon Web Services (AWS).

Configuring an endpoint with the AWS Signature authentication type

As a prerequisite, obtain an access key ID and a secret access key from the AWS Management Console. Alternatively, if you use temporary security credentials, not long-term credentials, to sign requests, generate these keys as well as a session token by using AWS Security Token Service (STS). For details, see the AWS documentation.

Field Value
Agent

Select Agentless.
Authentication type Select AWS Signature.
Access key ID Enter the access key ID.

Secret access key

 Enter the secret access key.
Session token
(only if you use temporary security credentials to sign requests)
 		 Enter the session token.
Certificate type Leave it empty.
Certificate format Leave it empty.
Server certificate

Leave it empty.

After completing the configuration, click Test connection to validate the configuration.
